titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Terence Sellers Papers
1967-2000
MSS 167
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Jenny Pachucki, 2007. Finding aid completed by Luke Martin and Christine Woody, 2009.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-11-14T17:31-0500

did.abstract: The Terence Sellers Papers include materials that relate to the art and literary scene in New York City in the 1970s and 1980s. The collection includes Sellers' writing, journals, photographs, and materials relating to her career as a professional writer.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The Terence Sellers papers were purchased by the Fales Libary and Special Collections from Terence Sellers in 2005.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); Terence Sellers papers; MSS 167; [box number]; [folder number], Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Terence Sellers was born to Robert and Gloria Sellers in Washington DC. From 1970-1973 she attended St. John's College in Santa Fe, New Mexico in the Classical Studies department but did not complete her degree. She earned a BA in forensic psychology at John Jay College in New York City in 1986.

In 1973 Sellers moved to New York City intending to pursue a career in writing and dance. Shortly after moving to New York she formed friendships with artists and writers including Anya Phillips, Kathy Acker, Duncan Smith, Victor Bockris, Carl Apfelschnitt, Jimmy De Sana and Duncan Hannah, many of which resulted in collaborations. For example, Sellers and Hannah worked on several projects together, including Amos Poe's 1978 film The Foreigner. Around the same time Sellers worked with photographer Jimmy De Sana on a series of 32 photographs entitled "The Dungeon Series". The original intent of the project was to use the photographs in Sellers' then unpublished work The Correct Sadist. However, after the work was complete De Sana and William S. Burroughs used the photographs to illustrate their own book project, Submission.

As a prolific writer, Sellers kept daily journals, maintained close correspondence with friends, family and colleagues, wrote a large volume of short stories and worked on several manuscripts. She was an early contributor to BOMB Magazine, X Magazine, Vacation and other publications devoted to New York's Downtown art, music, film and literary scene.

Most of Sellers' writing is on the subject of sadomasochism. While her work as a professional dominatrix and her fascination with violence, self-punishment, the occult, and psychoanalysis has given shape to much of her writing, her literary influences include Baudelaire, Dostoevsky, and the French surrealists.

Sellers' most famous work is a novel called the The Correct Sadist: The Memoirs of Angel Stern. It is written as a collection of short "case studies" relating to themes of sexual dominance and submission, bondage and discipline, and fetishism. Originally published by iKoo-Buchverlg in Berlin in 1981 as Der korrekte Sadismus, Sellers self-published the work in English under Vitriol Publications in 1983. In 1985, Grove Press contracted the novel and Barney Rosset handled its publication. It is also published in France, Italy, and the United Kingdom.

Sellers' other published novels include The Obsession, and Dungeon Evidence: The Correct Sadist II. Excerpts from other manuscripts such as The Degenerate, Most Ill of All and One Decadent Life have appeared in a wide range of publications in several languages. Sellers participated in events such as The Times Square Show (1980) and has read her work throughout the US, Europe and Canada. Although Sellers did not achieve the name recognition and literary success of some of her contemporaries, she is an important and influential member of the Downtown scene.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Terence Sellers Papers contain materials that relate to the literary career of Terence Sellers from the 1970's through the 1990's. Materials include journals, personal and professional correspondence, photographs, original artwork used in published works, manuscript materials, audio cassette recordings, and publicity materials relating to her published projects.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Terence Sellers papers are organized into seven series:

p.emph: Series VII: Academic and Biographical Materials

arrangement.p: Series I: Correspondence and Series II: Journals have been arranged chronologically. Series III: Subject Files, Series IV: Writing, Series VI: Business and Series VII: Academic and Biographical Materials have been arranged alphabetically. Series V: Photographic Materials has been arranged alphabetically by photographer. Series VIII and XI have been retained in the order in which they were found.

Although they are physically separate, oversize materials are assigned folder numbers that reflect their place in the overall organization of the series. This is to indicate where they fall in the alphabetical or chronological order.

list.item: Series VII: Academic and Biographical Materials

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at Fales Library and Special Collections

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers. Appointments are necessary for the use of manuscript and archival collections.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Collection use is subject to all copyright laws. Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the Director of Fales Library and Special Collections. Please contact fales.library@nyu.edu. or call 212 998 2596.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Terence Sellers' personal and business related correspondence from the 1970s through the 1990s, and includes snapshots, small mixed media drawings and paintings, and various printed materials. There is extensive correpondence between Sellers and Genesis P-Orridge, and Duncan Smith. The series also contains correspondence between Sellers and Kathy Acker, and others. Materials are organized chronologically by date, grouped by person or subject. Many folders include both correspondence to and from Sellers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes Sellers' journals that detail her personal life and professional life. Many of the journals also serve as early drafts for literary works and related to specific projects and subjects. Some journals also include clippings, photographs, and postcards.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains material that Sellers collected and organized that relates to specific literary projects and publications, subjects and events. Materials include journals, handwritten notes and correspondence, short stories and various printed materials.

did.unittitle: Books by Bob (Parody on her father, John Robert "Bob" Sellers)
"Chris Parker: Cover of German Film Magazine"

"She, The Other": Francois Peraldi on Terence Sellers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series IV: Writings is divided into five subseries according to genre. Subseries A contains Sellers' short stories, poems and plays, organized alphabetically. Subseries B includes Sellers' novels, organized alphabetically by title. These materials also include research for each project including notes, manuscripts, drafts, proofs, and promotion and publication materials. Subseries C contains original artwork by Jeffrey Bretschneider and Carl Apfelschnitt that was produced to illustrate editions of her published work. Subseries D is a scrapbook that Sellers created of clippings from magazines and newspapers relating to her life and literary career. Subseries E includes copies of Sellers' published essays and prose works, including various editions of works. Original folders are also included with most of the work in this series because in many instances Sellers took notes and brainstormed on her original folders. All work is arranged alphabetically by project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes audiocassettes that Sellers recorded in the 1970s. Materials include a recorded interview with Jimmy De Sana for Vacation Magazine in 1981 as well as recordings of Sellers reading her own poems and text from her published writing. Please see a Fales archivist about the availability of access copies.
